conclusion: Determine the farthest vertical distance from the wellhead water surface that the frog can see when it looks up from the bottom of the well.
The frog is at the bottom of the well, which is filled with water. The well has a depth of 8 meters and a radius of 0.5 meters. The refractive index of water is given as n = 4/3.
The critical angle (C) is the angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs. It can be calculated using Snell's Law.
Calculate the critical angle using Snell's Law: sin C = 1/n = 3/4, therefore C = arcsin(3/4).
The frog can see the scenery outside the well up to the angle C from the vertical. The light rays that reach the frog from the edge of the wellhead make an angle C with the vertical.
Calculate the maximum horizontal distance x from the center of the well to the edge of the visible area using trigonometry: tan C = x/8, therefore x = 8 tan C.
Calculate tan C using the identity tan C = sin C/sqrt(1 - sin^2 C): tan C = 3/sqrt(7).
Substitute tan C into the equation for x: x = 8 * (3/sqrt(7)) = 24/sqrt(7).
Calculate the farthest vertical distance from the wellhead water surface that the frog can see: Farthest distance = 24/sqrt(7) + 0.5.
The farthest vertical distance from the wellhead water surface that the frog can see is approximately 9.56 meters.
